In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The global financial crisis that emerged from the meltdown of the mortgage market in the 
United States in 2007 and spread to the world in 2008–2009 highlighted deficiencies and 
weaknesses  in  the  current  international  financial  architecture  as  well  as  national  financial 
regulatory  systems.  In  response  to  these,  the  Group  of  Twenty  (G-20)  leaders  made 
commitments to build a more resilient financial system. Subsequently, G-20 finance ministers 
and central bank governors, in consultation with the International Monetary Fund, tasked the 
Basel  Committee  on  Banking  Supervision  and  the  Financial  Stability  Board  (FSB)  to 
recommend ways to strengthen oversight and supervision of the financial sector, with the aim of 
building a resilient international financial system that can withstand shocks and mitigate their 
adverse effects on the real economy.1 
 
2.  Much progress has been made since the first commitments made by the G-20 leaders at 
the Washington summit in November 2008. In accordance with the G-20’s guiding principles, 
the FSB and its constituents sculpted specific reform proposals to strengthen financial stability. 
The first concrete outcome was the Basel III package of capital and liquidity reforms, which was 
endorsed by the G-20 leaders at the November 2010 Seoul summit. The new rules are planned 
to be implemented from January 2013 and are expected to be fully phased in by 1 January 
2019.  In  February  2011,  the  FSB  reported  progress  in  the  implementation  of  the  G-20 
recommendations on financial regulation. The report outlined further work toward dealing with 
systemically important financial institutions, strengthening the regulation and oversight of the 
“shadow  banking”  system,2 improving  over-the-counter  derivatives  market  and  credit  rating 
agencies,  developing  macro-prudential  frameworks,  and  making  progress  in  international 
harmonization of high-quality accounting standards. 
 
3.  These reforms have focused on strengthening global regulatory guidelines such as the 
Basel III standards, filling the regulatory gaps, and broadening the coverage. However, there is 
not yet an effective and collaborative implementation mechanism at the national level. As the 
urgency of the crisis fades, the push for reforms also seems to be weakening, which makes it 
harder  to  achieve  the  political  cohesion  needed  to  establish  a  harmonized  cross-border 
regulatory environment. 
 
4.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  as  the  region’s  main  development  bank  and 
multilateral body for policy counseling, plays an important role in providing an avenue for policy 
dialogues  and  cooperation  in  the  region.  Strategy  20203 underscores  the  importance  of 
providing knowledge platforms to ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs). In addition, 
ADB’s recently approved financial sector operational plan prepared by the Office of Regional 
Economic Integration (OREI) aims to respond better to the region’s need for financial sector 
development and ensure the quality and consistency of its operations.4 This research and

development technical assistance (TA) will promote the region’s financial sector development 
and policy cooperation in line with the financial sector operational plan, hence serving OREI’s 
core mandate. 
 
5.  Under this TA, ADB will leverage the existing regional platforms, such as the Association 
of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and ASEAN+35 meetings, to emphasize the need to 
strengthen  regional  cooperation  for  financial  regulatory  reforms.  Regional  policy  dialogues 
should promote adherence to international standards and minimum regulatory principles, and 
ensure  adequate  information  on  cross-border  financial  activities  and  effective  knowledge 
sharing. 
 
6.  This TA aims to support regulatory reforms in line with international good practices, 
covering  the  financial  sector  (banking,  insurance,  and  securities)  of  DMCs  in  East  and 
Southeast Asia. 6 The TA will examine the relevance of the global reform issues and their 
implications for emerging Asian economies, strengthen macro-prudential supervision of the 
DMCs through knowledge sharing, and help improve national regulatory systems and promote 
harmonization of national regulations and practices in line with global standards. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.7 
 
II.  ISSUES 
7.  Following the crisis and the G-20 responses to it, significant reforms have taken place to 
build a stronger, more globally consistent supervisory and regulatory framework for the financial 
sector. Although these reforms are critical to the future worldwide financial system, emerging 
economies  expressed  concerns  that  many  issues  focus  on  developed  economies  with 
advanced financial markets, and that the ongoing reforms may have little direct relevance to the 
challenges  facing  emerging  economies  and  financial  systems,  especially  those  with  less-
developed financial systems. 
 
8.  The real challenges are in the implementation of the global guidelines and policies at the 
national level. First is the implementation of Basel III. Second, the growing cross-border banking 
and financial activities imply that financial oversight must be coordinated internationally. Finally, 
the region should work with the global community to build solidified defenses against similar 
crises in the future. The crisis also highlighted the importance of adequate information on cross-
border  financial  activities  and  effective  knowledge  sharing.  However,  because  of  the  wide 
spectrum of financial development stages in developing countries, global financial reforms pose 
different challenges to DMCs—although they share important common goal of ensuring that 
domestic financial regulatory systems keep pace with global standards while promoting financial 
sector development. 
 
9.  The impact of the crisis differed across developing Asian economies depending on the 
degree of economic and financial openness, as well as the dependency on external demand 
and credit.8 Although exports and growth slowed in some Asian economies, their financial 
systems remained generally resilient because of their limited exposure to the problem assets. 
                                                
5 ASEAN+3 countries include the 10 members of ASEAN plus the People's Republic of China, Japan, and the 
Republic of Korea. 
6  The TA will cover DMCs in East and Southeast Asia. In this document, “DMCs” will refer to countries in those 
regions. 
7  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 June 2011.

3
Their relative resilience can also be attributed to the financial reforms undertaken after the 
1997/98 Asian financial crisis, which produced progressive improvements in the underlying 
financial infrastructure.  
 
10.  Despite the region’s generally positive financial sector performance, the global financial 
crisis again highlights the need to address the remaining reform agendas and issues specific to 
DMCs in the region. DMCs are lagging in their macro-prudential supervisory system to monitor 
potential risks arising from internal and external sectors. The lack of an early warning system, 
together with both human and physical capacity constraints, is an impediment to timely analysis 
of the macroeconomic and financial situation. Regulatory and supervisory weaknesses remain 
at  the  micro  level,  especially  in  the  quality  of  regulation,  resolution  of  problem  financial 
institutions, and cross-border cooperation. These weaknesses are often detrimental to effective 
crisis prevention and management by DMCs.9 
 
11.  The key lesson of the crisis is the need to enhance mechanisms to address economic 
and financial stability. Without collective efforts to secure the stability of the system, the stability 
of an individual economy cannot be guaranteed. To build a more resilient financial system, the 
region  needs  to  work  on  two  important  fronts.  First  is  the  adoption  of  an  internationally 
consistent framework that will mandate minimum regulatory principles and guidelines in the 
region.  The  national  authorities  need  to  strengthen  adherence  to  such  supervisory  and 
regulatory  standards.  Second  is  the  monitoring  and  management  of  capital  flows.  Many 
emerging Asian economies are facing massive capital inflows in the post-crisis period. Large 
and sudden capital inflows tend to push up the local currency value, lead to asset price bubbles, 
and risk overheating the economy. Experiences in many DMCs testify to the risk of volatile 
capital flows. 
 
12.  Asia’s DMCs need to undertake deeper and more comprehensive reforms to accelerate 
financial  sector  development.  For  DMCs,  the  most  important  development  issue  is  the 
fortification of the financial regulatory system, which can contribute to financial stability and 
economic growth. The region’s policymakers are concerned that the weaknesses of the financial 
regulatory system continue to hold back necessary progress toward responsible finance for the 
poor as well as micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises.10 
 
13.  The TA will address the issues of regulatory reforms from a new post-crisis perspective. 
It will (i) examine how Asian economies translate the lessons of the recent global financial crisis 
into appropriate policies and reform measures in terms of macro-prudential supervision relative 
to  micro-prudential  supervision;11 (ii)  assess  the  robustness  of  financial  sector  policies  or

the micro-prudential framework)—which tends to focus primarily on the stability of individual institutions, markets, 
and infrastructure—underestimates systemic risks. By contrast, the macro-prudential approach to supervision 
focuses mainly on the financial system as a whole and involves monitoring, assessment, and mitigation of systemic 
risk—the likelihood of failure of a significant part of the financial system. Thus, macro-prudential framework aims to

reforms  to  buffer  any  systemic  vulnerability  to  financial  crises,  and  the  extent  of  their 
contribution to financial soundness and stability; and (iii) help develop the strategic direction of 
the financial  policies  and  regulatory  reforms  through  consultations  with  officials from  DMC 
finance ministries, central banks, and supervisory agencies.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact of the TA will be improvements in the regulatory systems of the participating 
DMCs  through  sequential  actions  toward  global  standards  and  guidelines  to  address  the 
deficiency  of  their  financial  regulatory  regimes  and  vulnerability  to  financial  shocks.  With 
effective policy recommendations and action plans for individual DMCs, the TA will lay the 
foundations for regional initiatives to harmonize regulatory rules and practices with a view to 
strengthening regional financial and macroeconomic stability. The outcome will be a stronger 
regulatory  framework  through  the  adoption  of  global  standards  and  guidelines  in  the 
participating DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA comprises the following activities and outputs: 
(i)  Regional study. A regional study featuring assessments of the existing regimes 
and necessary reforms by the participating DMCs will be published. This will help 
DMCs assess their existing regulatory systems, identify the reforms needed at 
both the national and regional levels, and provide practical guidelines for Asian 
policy makers in designing their financial market development plans by mapping 
out  the  framework  for  regulatory  reforms  in  line  with  the  global  guidelines. 
Specifically, the study will provide an analysis of the following issues relevant to 
the region: (a) developing a macro-prudential supervisory system, (b) improving 
the  legal  and  institutional  framework  (especially  with  a  view  to  enhancing 
transparency and disclosure), and (c) managing capital flows. To provide better 
illustrations and understanding of these issues at the national level, the study will 
include selected country case studies. 
(ii)  Workshops  and  seminars.  Workshops  and  seminars  will  be  conducted  to 
increase awareness of the issues on financial regulatory reforms, provide venues 
for policy debates, and disseminate research outputs and recommendations. 
 
16.  The regional study together with four working papers under this TA will involve research, 
consultations, and statistical analysis. Partnerships with the World Bank and other international 
financial institutions or international standard setters will be explored for the purposes of building 
databases and conducting workshops and seminars.12 Strong collaboration with ADB regional 
                                                                                                                                                       
prevent or at least contain the potential risks derived from financial and macroeconomic imbalances and ensure 
that the financial system is able both to withstand shocks and to dampen their effects on the real economy. 
12 The World Bank proposed a joint Asia regional study in 2010. The TA is a response to that proposal. The study 
jointly conducted by ADB and the World Bank, Financial Stability Regulatory Reforms: Lessons from Global 
Financial Crisis for Asia Region, aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of how Asian economies responded to 
the global financial crisis and translate the lessons from the crisis into the Asian context. The original proposal 
included six topics: (i) reassessing the regulatory and supervisory framework, (ii) corporate governance and 
excessive risk taking, (iii) crisis management mechanisms (debt resolution regimes and insolvency laws), (iv) 
enhancing transparency and disclosure, (v) asset bubbles and macro-prudential surveillance, and (vi) improving 
access to finance. Given the budget constraint and the region’s priorities, the scope of the study was narrowed to 
four major themes listed in this TA paper. The partnership will be valuable to ADB's knowledge operations as it will 
enable ADB to access a wider research network and tap a larger pool of talent and broader range of expertise, 
especially in terms of financial sector assessment.

5
departments will be essential to increase access to information by DMCs, maximize the study’s 
operational  value,  and  utilize  existing  studies  by  regional  departments  for  more  advanced 
analysis of macroeconomic and financial links for DMCs. This collaboration could feed into the 
program or project designs to help governments put in place more robust macro-prudential 
frameworks to avert similar crises. 
 
17.  The  TA  will  use  ADB’s  new  financial  sector  operational  plan  in  formulating  its 
recommendations and reforms to meet the selected DMCs’ financial sector development needs. 
Linking the TA outputs to the operational plan will help provide more consistent and institution-
wide assistance to DMCs and strengthen ADB’s financial sector development operations. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which (i) the equivalent of $500,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund; 
and (ii) the equivalent of $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector 
Development Partnership Fund, both administered by ADB.13 The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The TA will be implemented by OREI from 
September 2011 to July 2014.14 Six international consultants with an estimated 20 person-
months of consulting services and four national consultants with 71 person-months of consulting 
services will assist in the implementation of the TA. Resource persons for workshops and 
seminars will also be engaged. 
 
20.  The terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. Individual consultants and 
resource persons will be hired according to ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, 
as amended from time to time). TA funds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, amended from time to time). 
 
21.  ADB will purchase equipment (e.g., computer hardware and software, databases) in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and in 
coordination  with  ADB’s  Office  of  Information  Systems  and  Technology  and  Office  of 
Administrative Services, where applicable. After the TA is completed, any equipment that was 
procured  will  be  disposed  of  in  compliance  with  the  project  administration  instructions  on 
administering grant-financed TA.15 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000, to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, and (ii) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000, to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund for Financial Regulatory 
Reforms in Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Individual international consultants, national consultants, and resource persons will be 
engaged under the technical assistance (TA). International consultants will mainly assist in (i) 
studying topics related to financial regulatory reforms at global, regional, and national levels; (ii) 
building  a  comprehensive  database  on  Asian  financial  sector  and  regulatory  systems;  (iii) 
delivering workshops and seminars on regulatory reforms to officials from finance ministries, 
central  banks,  and  supervisory  authorities  in  developing  member  countries  in  East  and 
Southeast Asia; and (iv) producing summary reports and working papers on macro-prudential 
surveillance, regulatory systems and infrastructure, capital flow management, and strategies for 
reform policies. National consultants will assist staff of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  in  data  collection  and  research;  organization  of 
workshops  and  seminars;  and  the  planning,  design,  and  delivery  of  TA  outputs,  including 
assistance in administration and logistics, as needed. Resource persons will be engaged to 
review the draft background papers and the publications, and to participate in workshops and 
seminars. The consultants and resource persons will be selected and engaged in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
A.  Lead Economist (1 international consultant, 9 person-months) 
 
2.  In  consultation  with  the  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration,  an  international 
consultant with expertise in the financial sector (banking, insurance, and/or capital markets) will 
be hired as the lead consultant. The lead consultant will be assigned to manage and oversee 
the comprehensive regional study backed by the sound database built for the study on the 
implications of global financial regulatory reforms for developing Asia’s financial systems. He or 
she should have knowledge of financial regulatory practices and work experience in economic 
analysis. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the lead consultant will: 
(i)  guide  the  technical  experts,  who  will  jointly  be  responsible  for  ensuring  the 
study’s analytical structure and economic relevance; 
(ii)  coordinate and consolidate the work of the experts; 
(iii)  provide direction on the identification of specific topics to be covered by the 
study; 
(iv)  write case studies and analytical papers assigned by ADB staff; 
(v)  discuss strategic aspects of the study with the technical experts, help ADB staff 
coordinate their work, and liaise with the economic editor to ensure that the final 
report is of high standard and quality; 
(vi)  incorporate comments from the workshops and draft a group report; 
(vii)  finalize, together with the technical experts, the group report, working papers, 
and regional study for publication; 
(viii)  develop a database on the implications of global financial regulatory reforms for 
developing Asia’s financial system; and 
(ix)  attend  and  make  presentations  during  the  seminars  and  workshops  to  be 
organized under this TA. 
 
B.  Technical Experts (3–4 international consultants, 10 person-months) 
 
3.  Economists or technical experts will be hired to prepare working papers under the 
general guidance of the lead consultant and the ADB project manager. They will also serve as 
resource  persons  in  the  seminars  and  workshops  to  be  organized  under  this  TA.  The 
consultants will: 
(i)  write working papers on topic(s) assigned by the ADB staff;

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  provide advice on the identification of topics; 
(iii)  liaise closely with the lead consultant; 
(iv)  present  the  research  findings  in  seminars  and  workshops,  and  participate 
actively in the workshops; 
(v)  incorporate comments from the workshops and draft the group report; and 
(vi)  help finalize the working papers and regional study for publication. 
 
C.  Manuscript and Copyeditor (1 international consultant, 1 person-month) 
 
4.  The manuscript and copyeditor will (i) edit the working papers and regional study in 
accordance with ADB’s editorial style; (ii) be responsible for proofreading the text, tables, and 
charts of the publications from the preliminary draft to the final copy; (iii) ensure data integrity 
and consistency in the final manuscript; and (iv) be involved in rounds of revisions to ensure that 
the papers do not contain grammatical mistakes or misprints before forwarding to the printer. 
 
D.  Typesetter (1 national consultant, 2 person-months) 
 
5.  The typesetter will lay out the regional study and convert the files into the required 
format for print and/or online publication. In consultation with and under the guidance of ADB 
staff, the consultant will (i) design the regional study cover and lay out the text, tables, and 
charts of the regional study in Adobe InDesign CS2 and Adobe Illustrator CS2; (ii) incorporate 
revisions to the text, tables, and charts; and (iii) convert the Adobe files into PDF files for online 
and print publication. 
 
E.  Economic Analyst and Project Coordinator (1 national consultant, 23 person-months) 
 
6.  The economic analyst and project coordinator will assist the ADB project manager in 
administering the TA. He or she (i) will provide research assistance to the project team, (ii) 
should have knowledge on financial regulatory practices and work experience in economic 
analysis, (iii) will assist the international consultants in building the database and drafting reports, 
(iv) will assist in liaising and coordinating with ADB staff and counterparts in other institutions 
when organizing seminars and workshops, and (v) will be responsible for the administrative 
duties in the organization of the seminars and workshops.  
 
F.  Economic Analysts (2 national consultants, 46 person-months) 
 
7.  The  economic  analysts  (i)  will  provide  research  assistance  to  the  international 
consultants; (ii) should have knowledge on regional (East Asia and Southeast Asia) financial 
regulatory practices and work experience in economic analysis; and (iii) will assist the project 
team in building database, conducting country case studies, drafting reports, and preparing and 
conducting seminars and workshops. 
 
G.  Resource Persons (9–12 resource persons, 1.1 person-months) 
 
8.  Resource persons will be engaged for short periods to review the draft research papers 
and attend the workshops and seminars.
